text: Tiny golden  wheels and gears turning lazily upon metal rods. Mechanic intricate. Glittering in the sunlight.

The gears are  turning within an ANTIQUE DESK CLOCK sitting on a book sh swinging back and forth behind the glass housing. The room is  barren except for a pair of open suitcases and a bed that Sitting on the mattress is ...
Smart and  clever. Dressed in a graduation gown and staring out the lost in thought, immobile, until the bedroom door swings
aged seventeen and wearing a suit and tie, steps inside.
Dad says we  gotta get moving. We're late.
I'm getting  ready.
You're sitting  on the bed.
(dryly) Thanks for  clearing that up. I'll be right down. He steps  out. Julia takes a  framed picture out of her suitcase -- a candid shot of he MOTHER, forties, a healthy and vibrant woman.
(cont'd) Sure do miss  you. Above her, a  CEILING FAN rotates. Creating a soft HUMMING.
Julia walks out  of the building where her father, GUY LEVIN, an older man waits. Connor is checking his reflection in the car windo fussing with his hair.
You ready?
All set. I  packed up everything. (remembering) Oh, except  Mom's clock -- I think there's something wrong with it. I right time.
I'll get it  fixed. Probably just needs a few new parts. Guy smiles at  Julia for a moment. Very warmly.
(cont'd) You look just  like your mother. Julia is  momentarily uncomfortable. But she recovers, smiles and k cheek.
We'll be  late.
Students  dressed in graduation caps and gowns are gathered on the Julia stands by  herself, taking pictures with a professional Nikon camera camera upon ...

beautiful and sexy. Very particular and demanding. She sm snaps the picture. But her boyfriend, SAM BURNSIDE, cute sporting pink hair and loud clothes, makes a face. Winding her  film, Julia searches a moment, then smiles. Raising her c picture of ...
Early twenties.  Dark hair. Strapping and perfectly handsome. He wears a b tie with his starched white shirt and graduation gown. He kisses her.  Passionate and gentle.
You packed  up?
Ready to move  in. I'll be storing some of the stuff you've already got. Microwave.
(suggestively) Bed. Julia smiles at  him.
Bed.
Med School  doesn't start until August. At least not for the freshmen of time to see Europe, take the car trip up north ...
I hope it won't  be a drag. There's a lot of stuff to move out of my mothe
Our friends  will be there. It'll be fun.
I hope so. Beat.
You okay?
Tense.
Would it help  if I massaged your breasts?
No.
Because it  would help me.
(stifling  laughter) Maybe  later. The students  start forming into lines.
(cont'd) Hey, I saw your  Mom and kid sister. Where's your Dad? Beat.
He's not  coming.
But it's your  graduation. Paul shrugs  again. A brief sting of hurt on his face.
Wasn't a good  enough reason in High School either. Paul looks  away. Julia knows how painful this is and won't insult hi it. Julia smiles  and runs her finger across his tie knot.
I like your  tie. UCLA colors.

School spirit.  I am a Bruin. The lines start  moving towards the stadium. Hundreds of CHEERS rise up fr students. As she walks, a  sound draws Julia's attention. Standing on the lawn is a four years-old, SOBBING and clinging to his mother's legs Julia stops  walking as she gazes at the child. The line comes to a ha
(cont'd) Julia. We can't  graduate unless you move.
Sorry. She stalks  walking again. Paul puts his arms around her.
A big,  traditional house nestled in the hills. PARENTS and gradu polite conversation in the yard.
Sitting between  a pair of open french doors is "the gang" consisting of J and Sam. They throw around conversation, ignoring the par
It's secluded?  Nobody said anything to me about the cabin being secluded
I said it was a  cabin in the woods. I thought seclusion was a given.
I'm no good out  in the woods. You know what lives in the woods? Animals t bite.
So avoid the  animals.
I really  appreciate you guys helping me. I couldn't move everythin
Hey, it's our  last chance to be together. Terry and I are excited. (turns) Aren't we,  Ter? She's not  excited.
Can I bring my  cotton bedsheets to the cabin? If I try to sleep in anyth hives.
Whatever makes  you happy. Sam grabs a  large drawing pad from the steps. He opens it.
Speaking of  which, I've got your graduation gift. As specified.
Let's see. Sam holds up a  sketch of Clark Kent changing to Superman.
Like it?
It's great.  Thanks Sam. Paul checks out  the drawing. His nose crinkles.
Superman? Why'd  you want a drawing of Superman?
He's very  attractive.
(staring) You're  kidding.
No.
He's not even  real.
I think most  women tend to wonder if Superman is super in  every way.
I don't.
You see. There  goes your argument.
(thoughtfully) But Spiderman  has a nice ass. Off everyone's
(cont'd) What?
Julia finishes  washing her hands. Dries them. Grabbing her camera and th the bathroom door ...
... and  freezes. Standing within an open bedroom is ...

Another college  graduate. Tan and attractive. Dressed exactly like Paul - shirt, gold and blue striped tie. He pulls off his tie an shirt. Julia doesn't  move. The student  peels off his shirt. Her eyes are drawn to a Superman "S" his shoulder. The student  catches sight of Julia in the hallway. Her face turns bri She starts to laugh. He smiles at  her. A bit flattered. Flirting.
Changing into  something more formal. He holds up a  pair of ripped jeans. Julia backs  down the hallway. Still laughing. Embarrassed.
I'm sorry. I  was just using the ... (laughs) Really. I'm  sorry.
I'll forgive  you this once. She quickly  leaves. The blond  student watches her go. A grin on his face.
Julia walks out  the back door. Stifling her laughter. Paul is talking  with Guy on the lawn. Julia SNAPS a picture of them toget and notices ...

Sweet and  innocent. Sitting on a bench. Motionless. Julia walks  towards her. The little girl is staring across the lawn a Transfixed. A group of children are playing on the grass The girl  becomes aware of Julia's presence and turns around.
Hi.
(quiet) Hi. Silence.
You sitting  here all by yourself? The girl slowly  nods "Yes."
(cont'd) Don't you want  to play with the other kids? The girls  shakes her head "No."
(cont'd) Want me to  leave you alone? The girl shakes  her head "No." More  silence.
(cont'd) Want to mix  this up and ask me something? The little girl  notices the camera.
Are you taking  pictures for Sam's family?
No, I'm just  ... (then) I'm a friend of  Sam's. But I'm also a photographer. I take pictures. Beat.
Will you take a  picture of me?
Why?
So you won't  forget me.
(surprised) Why would I  forget you?
Because they're  coming for me. A long beat.  Julia sits next to her.
Who is?
The  monsters.
What  monsters?
There. Behind  the door. The girl points  towards the pool shed. The rusted door of the shed is sli crack.
Those other  kids don't look too scared.
They should  be. Beat.
(playing  along) So how come  only you can see them?

head_text.subj: FORWARD AND SPEAKS IN A HUSHED WHISPER.

text: Because I know  they're real. I used to have a little brother, but  they came and got him.  Now my parents say I never had a brother before. (pause) Soon ... my  parents won't remember me either. Something about  the girl's tone of voice is unnerving. As if she's resign A slight wind  HISSES through the trees. The girl rises.
(cont'd) I gotta go.  They know I'm talking about them.
Wait a  second. Julia SNAPS a  picture of the girl.
(cont'd) Feel  better? The girl stares  at her.
Are you scared  of monsters?
No. Beat.
I am. The girl turns  and runs across the lawn. Julia is left  sitting on the bench. She glances over at the pool shed a and focuses on the door which is still cracked open. She snaps the  picture.
Julia and Paul  are romantically entangled as they enter the apartment. A and frolicking. She strips off his jacket and tie. Paul a

Wait a minute  ... (grabbing  both sides of his shirt) This is a job  for ... Paul rips his  shirt wide open. Buttons popping everywhere. They both st together, he guides her towards the bathroom. The wind gently  HISSES on the balcony. Windchimes spinning.

A cloud of hot  steam. The soothing rush of warm water running over tanne Julia stands  underneath the shower, her body relaxing into Paul's ches encircling her body, his lips buried in her neck and shou shut. Her expression is calm.
Standing in the  guest bedroom at Sam's house. Young and muscular. Bathed on his shoulder.
Her eyes still  pressed closed. Smiling a little. Water continues  rushing from the shower head, creating a HISS that eventu OF THE OCEAN.
The setting sun  blushes crimson across the rolling waves of the Pacific. highway is a RANGE ROVER, packed with luggage, headlights

Paul sits  behind the wheel. He's bopping and RAPPING with Sam to HI the speakers. Very energized. Julia sits on  the passenger side, leaning against the window, trying to Terry looks just as miserable. Finally, Julia turns off t A silent beat.  The guys catch their girlfriends' expressions.
Sorry.
(overlapping) Sorry. Terry leans  forward between the seats.
So the cabin  has electricity, right? And plumbing? Everything we need?
Uh-huh.
So it has  everything.
It has  everything.
Wait a minute.  I hear a shoe about to drop.
Except a  phone.
BAM! There it  is.
(scandalized) I need a phone.  It's like family to me. Mom, Dad, my brother ....  phone .
So you're  roughing it.
The last time I  tried to rough it, I was in therapy for a year. Why didn' phone?
I guess she  wanted to be left alone. At least until  she got sick. Paul looks to  her.
This won't be  too hard on you, will it? Staying at her  place?
It's okay. I'm  enjoying this. Julia smiles at  him. Paul smiles back.
Good. He switches the  radio back on and continues RAPPING with Sam. Julia and T straight ahead, ears pounding. This is turning into a LON
Paul's Range  Rover makes its way down a long, winding road. The Rover' the woods lining the road on both sides.

The inside of  the Range Rover is dark. Only the faint glow from the das any ambient illumination. Sam and Terry are snuggled toge Everything is quiet. Julia is  thinking. Finally, she breaks the silence.
Do you believe  in monsters? A beat.  Everyone else in the car trades looks.
We've been in  the car too long.
I'm just  asking.
Like what? The  Boogeyman?
The Boogeyman.  The thing under the bed. The monster hiding in the closet
What made you  think of that?
A little girl  at Sam's house. She was convinced there was a monster try
You're saying  you believe her? Julia is  suddenly on the spot. She backtracks.
Of course I  don't. There are no monsters. Not really.
Sure there are.  Ted Bundy. Son of Sam. Ed Gein.
Who was Ed  Gein?
He was a mass  murderer. This old hermit who'd kill people and take the Livers. Intestines. Sex organs.
Why did he use  the parts for?
Everything. The  police found a skull that was used for a soup bowl. Faces mounted like hunting trophies on the wall. Bones were use
He also wore  their skin. Like clothes. Terry recoils  into her seat. Grossed out.
Sorry I  asked.
You wanted  proof. There it is.
But it's not  like he's a monster under the bed.
So?
So why are kids  afraid of that?

Because they  live in a completely different world than we do. (then) Think about it.  Why do kids pick up on things that we can't? ... Bumps in footsteps in the hallway? ... A thumping inside their clo
Overactive  imagination.
Wrong. Perfect  awareness. (beat) Kids have a  perfect awareness of everything around them. Every sound. Every  shadow. Everything gets  quiet.
(cont'd) The Boogeyman  could be real. So could monsters. Just because you've nev mean they aren't there. Silence. The  car engine purrs softly. This is starting to make sense.
All right. I'm  creeped out. But my bullshit alarm is going off.
You just can't  handle it.
Right. Because  it's bullshit.
Serial killers  aside, my take on this subject is very simple. If I don't -- it's not real.

Okay, is this  conversation like a radio station? Can we just change the personally, I'd like to get to sleep tonight. Terry has just  finished saying these words, when -- AN ANIMAL runs out of the woods into the  middle of the road. A black shape in the headlights. Eyes dark.
Paul SLAMS on  the brakes. Too late.
The RANGE ROVER SMASHES into it
throwing the shape into a ditch at the side of the road. The Range Rover  swerves and comes to a SQUEALING HALT.
Everyone  catches their breath. A moment of dead silence.
(cont'd) Everyone  okay?
(nods) We're fine.
What was  that?
I think it was  a dog. Julia unlocks  her door.
We'd better  check the car. She steps out  of the Rover. The others follow.
The hazard  lights are switched on. Paul walks around to the front of The bumper is  dented.
Look at that.  There's a couple thousand dollars out of my wallet.
You can  probably get someone to pop it back.
Sure. For a  couple hundred dollars. Sam looks down  the road. He can barely make out a large form resting lif He starts  walking towards it.
I'm sorry about  your car, Paul ...

(begrudging) Yeah, well.  Shit happens. The  conversation becomes distant as Sam walks slowly up the r yellow flashing HAZARD LIGHTS which CLICK rhythmically .. ... Sam approaches  the ditch. Darkness is all around. .... click ...  click ... click ... He kneels down  alongside the body of the animal. Very little is visible for its dark, mangled form sprawled across the dirt. Sam picks up a  stick and pokes at the body. Nothing happens. He pokes at the  corpse again. The hind legs  of the corpse suddenly twitch. A reflex action. Sam leaps scared out of him. A flap of  hairless skin slides away from one of the animal's hind l to get a better look, becoming simultaneously repulsed an
Hey guys!
What?
Take a look at  this.
Is it a  dog? Sam glances at  the dead corpse and back to his friends again. He looks s

I don't  know. The rest of the  group moves down the road. A weird unease has started to Paul and Julia  kneel down in front of the corpse. It's almost unrecogniz smothering the road keeps them from getting a handle on a features.
It looks like a  dog to me.
Did you see the  leg?

What about  it? Sam takes the  stick and gently pushes away the flap of torn skin for a leans forward. A deep bleeding  wound has been exposed. Through the torn flesh and blood skin, the group can see bones flashing into the moonlight the animal's skeleton are ...
Glittering and  clean. A series of connected stainless steel threads and grown together.
Ever seen  anything like that?
No.
It looks like  steel. Like someone put steel into its body.
I don't think  it was put in there. It looks like it grew that way.
That's  impossible. What kind of animal has steel in its skeleton Terry steps  forward tentatively.
What are you  looking at?
Are you sure  it's dead?
Come on, honey.  It's a dog. Not a zombie.
Julia? Where's  your camera?
It's in the  car.

I've got  it. Paul races back  to the Range Rover and opens the passenger door. He withd camera. Julia takes a  step back into the middle of the road. The wind is siftin creating a soft HISSING noise as the branches dance and t shadows. Paul returns  and hands the camera to Sam.
You want to  turn it over?

I'm not  touching it. Sam kneels  down. He points the camera and shoots. The camera  flash cuts through the darkness and falls upon the corpse millisecond of clarity. Twisted metal.  Skin. Appendages. Madness. Both of the  young men stand frozen, thunderstruck, staring down at th front of them. A long period of amazed silence follows.
That's wrong.  That's all wrong. Paul shakes his  head.
That's not a  dog.
(stunned) What were those  things coming out of its back? Paul starts  recoiling. His stomach is getting weak.
That's not a  dog. The cool summer  wind WHISTLES through the trees around them.
(sickened) That doesn't  even make  sense .
Paul ... Paul looks over  at her.
(cont'd) Let's get in  the car.
We need some  flashlights.
(hushed) Screw the  flashlights.
What the hell  is it?
Dude. We're  outta here. Julia and Paul  walk briskly to the Range Rover. Sam and Terry follow the their shoulders.
What the hell  is it?! Paul tosses the  camera into the Rover's back seat. He SLAMS the door shut passenger door. A soft THUMPING  from the woods. Almost like footsteps.
Get in the  car. Julia hops into  the front seat and SLAMS her door.
The atmosphere  is quickly turning into panic. Paul jumps behind the whee close their doors.
I want to know  what that thing was. Paul presses  the automatic door lock. THUNK.
Paul, start the  car.
Keys ... He searches his  pockets. They're empty. He checks his jacket.
I want to know  what it was.
Will you shut  up? Paul fishes out  the car keys from his jacket pocket. He starts the igniti life.
Go. A heavy THUMP.  Right outside the back window. Sam and Terry instinctivel hatch.
There's  something behind the car.
Paul hits the  gas.
The Range Rover  disappears into the night. The calm and  unnerving quiet of the woods are left behind. The wind WH
A fast food  joint at the side of the road.
Everyone is  sitting quietly at a table. Fast food leavings are litter trays. Nobody is saying anything or looking at one anothe Finally ...
I want to get  the body. Everyone's face  drops into shock. Paul almost laughs.
You do that.  We'll wait for your ass right here. Sam leans  forward in his seat. Intense.
Nothing about  that thing looked right. Absolutely nothing. There was me skeleton.
Maybe it wasn't  metal. It might've just looked like metal.
There were  fucking gears, for Chrissake.
Fine. Go back  out there. Do whatever the hell you want. But count me ou
We've already  got a picture, Sam.
Let's get a few  more then. I want to get a good look at that thing up clo
(adamant) I'm not going  back there.
Let Julia  decide. It's her camera. The group  stares at Julia. She remains silent.

Your call. Julia stares  back at all of them. A moment. A small CHILD  begins CRYING and SCREAMING in the restaurant. Julia flin sound, glancing over at the child's parents as they quiet She rises from  the table.
I have to use  the bathroom. She walks  straight into the bathroom. After she's  gone ...
I'm not going  back there.

Large and  poorly lit. Several closed bathroom stalls face a row of mirror. A toilet  FLUSHES. Julia leaves one of the stalls and pulls the doo She moves to the mirror, washes her hands, and retrieves purse. Water DRIPS  from one of the leaky pipes in the bathroom while the flu mirror CRACKLES softly. Julia is about to brush her hair, her. She cocks her head slightly. A feeling. She turns  around and checks out the bathroom. The doors to the stal Empty and quiet. She starts  brushing her hair. A few moments pass. Then, she stops an DRIPPING from the pipe. Julia turns back around and looks One of the  stall doors all the way at the end is now slightly open. to reveal a patch of darkness and gloom within. The sound of  water dripping abruptly stops. Silence follows. Julia looks  like she's about to crawl out of her skin. She quickly sh into her purse and leaves.
Julia walks  towards her friends as they collect themselves. Everyone stuff together.
I want to  leave.
Hold up. We're  coming. The CHILD  starts CRYING again. Pointing at the bathroom. This disturbs  Julia further.
Paul?
Okay. Slow  down. The group  leaves the table.

The group  emerges from the restaurant. The parking lot is almost de in sight. Julia moves  leisurely towards the Range Rover, just ahead of Terry an a lot faster if Paul's arm weren't draped around her shou and nervous. Her eyes scanning the parking lot. The cars are  empty. Sidewalk litter dances in the wind. Inside one of the parked cars, a featureless  SHAPE is sitting behind the wheel. The shape turns and st them. Everyone piles  into the Range Rover. Julia throws a nervous glance back car. He's still  watching them. Everyone piles  into the car.
Paul starts the  engine and pulls out of the parking lot. Julia relaxes in relieved.
The Range Rover  heads off into the woods.
A rustic home  surrounded by huge pine trees and beach grass overlooking no neighbors in sight. Paul's Range Rover is parked out f
The basement is  saturated in a bright red light. Julia is developing a ph basin. Paul and Terry are seated on the stairs. Sam is pa
How much  longer?
Thirty seconds.  It's coming out.
I still think  we should get the body. We could drive  out there, haul it into the car ...
I'm not loading  that thing into my car. I don't give a  shit what it is. It's not coming back here. Julia lifts the  developed picture out of the basin.
Done. She switches on  the light. The group crowds around her.
What is it?  What does it look like? The photograph  is blurred. The body is indistinguishable.
Damn.
What happened  to the picture?
Out of  focus.
What do you  mean it's out of focus? I took the picture. The flash wen
Sam, this is a  professional camera with a zoom lens. You can't just poin A quiet moment  as they stare at the picture.
Well, so much  for that. Sam looks at  the picture, then at his friends. With a look of somber f turns and charges up the stairs, taking two at a time. After he's gone  ...
It's not a big  deal. Whatever it was. (then) He'll get over  it.
Cloudy and  overcast. A set of colorless waves CRASH into the rocks. walk just beyond the rippling surf, arguing with each oth
I can't get  over it. That thing looked wrong. Completely wrong.
Of course it  looked wrong. Paul rammed it with his car.
What about the  blood? It wasn't red ... it was  black -- it was like ... oil coming from  a busted engine.
I must've  missed that.
Let's find it. Cut it up. Study  it.
(measured) Sam, I realize  that you're an extroverted comic book artist and I'm a ne now at this moment that I'm wondering why we're dating. Sam turns back  to Julia --
I'll pay you to  take me back.
You don't have  to pay me. Take the car.
The Rover's a  shift. I can only drive an automatic.
Ask Paul.
He's out  running. Besides, you heard him last night. He'd never do Julia stares at  him.
It's a dead  animal.
So come with  me. You take the pictures this time. If it's just a dead right and I'm wrong. But if it's not, we've got a picture
A picture of  what? Beat.
A monster. A set of  foaming waves HISS as they slide along the sand. Julia stands  with her arms folded. There's something really creepy abo want to admit.
Monsters don't  exist.
What...? (pause) Sayin' yes ...  or saying no? Julia stares at  him, deadpan. Sam just stares right back.
The same lonely  stretch of road from the night before. The Range Rover  appears around a corner and pulls over to the side of the door, camera in hand, and gets out. Sam follows her lead.
This is it?
I think so. You  can see the way the road turns sharply to the left. The r straight.
You've got  film, right?

A new roll. You  can have all the pictures you want. Julia and Sam  start searching the ditch. Feet crunching in the dirt. Mo car. A soft THUMP  echoes from somewhere in the woods. A place just beyond t branches and shrubbery that shivers in the breeze. Sam and Julia  look around. They wait. Nothing. Nobody.
(slight  grin) The Boogeyman  lives here.
So will you if  you keep talking like that. They keep  walking. A beat passes.
Julia? Can I  ask you something?
Go ahead.
Last night on  the road, after I took the picture and we started walking have the same feeling?
What  feeling?

That we were  being chased. Julia doesn't  say anything. She stops cold  in her tracks. Just ahead of her, resting motionless in t A BODY ... Swathed in dark  fur, twisted at a pathetic angle, huge gashes in its side Doberman pinscher . Flies are BUZZING  and swarming over the dog's open wounds. Julia and Sam  move towards the dog's lifeless form.
There's your  monster.
That's a  dog.
Right. Sam kneels in  front of the corpse. Waves off some flies.
That's not what  I saw.
I don't see any  other corpses on the side of the road, do you? A long moment.  Sam stares back down at the Doberman's body.
That's not what  I saw.
Eyes slightly  open. A misshapen form plagued with flies. The sound of  INSECTS SWARMING drowns out the WIND HISSING through the

Paul is jogging  through the woods. A light mist hangs in the cool air. Th surround him. Suddenly, the  birds stop singing. Paul becomes aware of this. He stops around. The forest is deathly still. The sound of a  TWIG being crushed underfoot. Then nothing. Another moment.  Paul keeps going, a chill on his spine, looking back over

A picture  postcard community consisting of quaint storefront shops parks. Paul stands  right in front of a freshly painted realty office buildin fence, sipping a Coke, watching a HOMELESS WOMAN across t screaming and  shouting at traffic. She's right next  to the parked Range Rover. Julia walks out  of the realty office.
Finished?
Done. The cabin  has a buyer.
What about the  movers?
They're coming  on Sunday afternoon so we'll have to start packing. The homeless  woman starts walking off down the sidewalk. Moving away f space.
Good. She's  leaving. I thought we were gonna have to make a run for t
I feel sorry  for those people.
Me too. But  that doesn't mean I want to get screamed at.
People are  ignoring her. Maybe that's the only way she can get atten
She's doing a  good job. Kept me away. They start  crossing the street towards the car.
How does  someone end up like that?
I think we're  witnessing it first-hand with Sam. What did you guys find anyway?
A dog. Paul stares at  her. Surprised.
Really?
Yeah.  Personally, I'm glad we didn't find Frankenstein's monste
You just like  being right.
(grins) Damn  straight.
Sam heads away  from the cabin, his drawing sketch pad under his arm, mov

A picture is  lifted out of the developing basin. The shot of the littl Her expression is distant. Tortured. Bathed in the  red light, Julia gazes at the picture for a moment, then She goes to work on the next piece of developing paper in waits. Rocks the basin a bit. The TIMER in  the basement TICKS. The picture  starts to manifest. The photo of the children and pool sh Julia frowns  slightly. Something is wrong with the photograph as the d tangible. She lifts the photo out of the basin. Mystified
Standing just inside the shed's door is a  BLURRED FIGURE. Featureless. Barely distinguishable. Hidi dark.
Sam is sitting  on a fallen tree trunk, sketching on his drawing pad with intensity.
A rough drawing  of the animal's leg, intertwined with steel rods and meta culminate in a large pulley where the hip bone should be.
A warm and  comfortable cabin. Simple and subdued. Paul is seated  on the couch, typing into his powerbook which is hooked u the wall. Julia stands next to him, holding the photograp
I've never seen  anything like this before. I thought it might be a flaw i I'm not so sure. Will you take a look?
(not  paying attention) Okay. He keeps  watching.
Today.
I'm busy.
You're in a  chat room with a bunch of strangers.
(defensive) They're  friends.
Oh yeah? What  are their last names? They sit face  to face. Paul is speechless for a moment, then impatientl and looks at it.
I don't see  anything. He puts the  photo down and gets back to the chat room.
You didn't even  look.
(he  didn't) I looked.
There's  somebody in the shed. I couldn't see it when I took the p there.
I know. Usually  when you take a picture, you can't see a blur. Paul smiles at  her. Completely smug. Julia stares right back.

Give your  "friends" my best. Julia takes the  photograph and leaves. Paul types into his computer: "JUL message pops up next to his user name. Within seconds, se in the chat room respond with "WHO'S JULIA???"
Terry is  sitting on the counter, twirling her hair and chatting on enters the kitchen.
(on  the phone) I'm not  kidding, Dana. There's no phone. (beat) There's a jack  and the phone line works, but there's  no phone . Uh-huh. Paul was  able to get on the internet. I'm using his cell.
(quietly) I need you to  look at something. Terry nods.
Hold on.
Here. Julia holds out  the picture. Terry looks it over briefly.
(polite) Nice  picture. She gets back  to her phone conversation.
(cont'd) I'm back. (beat) I don't know if  he has any free minutes, but he definitely won't after th Uh-huh. Thank God for AirTouch. Frustrated,  Julia takes the picture and leaves the kitchen.

The air is  completely still. A hush has fallen. The only sound is th crickets chirping in the grass. Julia wanders  outside holding some of the developed photographs from th on the front steps, working on his drawing.
Sam? Could you  look at... Sam looks up  from his drawing pad.
What? Beat.

Never mind. Julia sits on  the porch glider and looks through the photos. The little her shoulder. The blurred shape inside of the shed. A moment  passes. Julia shuts her eyes as a slight breeze comes up. dream-like state, calm and relaxed, before opening her ey

Sitting back on  the hood of a sports car. Wearing a white tank top unders insignia visible on his shoulder. Bathed in soft moonligh in the dark. Their eyes  meet. Smiles are traded between them. The wind sifts gent It's all very  dream-like .
A spacious  bedroom. Typical.  Julia is  already in bed and wearing a night shirt. Paul is grindin crunches.
It just would  have been nice if somebody had looked at it. You were on on the phone. I felt like I was living with a bunch of ma people.
Someone's  overreacting.
Would you look  at it again?
I already did.  And I still don't see anything.  Paul gets into  bed.
That little  girl said there was a monster in the shed.

(kisses  her) It was probably  another dog. Good night. He switches off  the light. Paul turns over and goes to sleep. Julia sits for  a moment in the dark. Alone with her thoughts. She looks closet across the room. The closet door  is slightly open. Just a crack. Not enough to provide any lies within, but just enough for something -- monsters in out. Julia stares at  the closet. Spooked. She knows better, but it's dark and taking control.
(to  herself) Stupid. She gets out of  bed and tiptoes to the closet, shutting the door. Then sh Smiling to herself, she goes to sleep.
The wind is  picking up. Trees rustle.

The clock on  the night table reads 3:15 AM. Julia turns over in her sl She groggily looks over towards the closet. Julia practic bed. The closet door is wide open. A childhood  nightmare come to life. Julia's breathing quickens. She r other side of the bed.

(a  whisper) Paul? Her hand finds  nothing but sheets and empty space. There's nobody there. locate her boyfriend. But he's gone. She tries to  switch on the light. CLICK. The light stays  off. She tries again. CLICK. Nothing  happens. Then, she hears  it. A faint sound. Almost like a  shuffling . The sound of something  dragging itself lightly across the floor to the edge of t Julia's throat  has gone dry. Carefully, she creeps towards Paul's side o the floor. There is  nothing in sight. The only sign of movement are the shado outside. There is only  one place left to look. Julia cautiously steps down to th on her knees, she gently lifts up the dust ruffle and loo darkness underneath the bed. The space is empty. Julia drops the  dust ruffle and sits up, GASPING.
Then, a  familiar voice comes from it.
Hey ... it's  just me. Paul switches  on the light. He's wearing a UCLA sweatshirt.
The light  wouldn't turn on.
Works now. Julia catches  her breath. The fear finally draining from her.
Where were  you?
I was cold so I  got a sweater from the closet. And I went to the bathroom under the bed? Julia isn't  quite sure how to answer. She's embarrassed.
I thought there  was something in the room.
(skeptical) Something? Like  what?
Packing tape is pulled back from a roll. Julia finishes  taping up a cardboard box. Terry is packing some books in own.
You thought there was a monster in the room? And  you admitted it?
I didn't know  what else to say.
Advice. When  you don't know what else to say, you lie.
But I really  did hear something.
You're worse  than my boyfriend. Julia looks  towards the front door. Sam is sitting  on the porch steps, sketching on his pad, oblivious to ev him.
He's in his own  world, isn't he?

That's an  understatement. I have a sinking feeling that sex is out this trip. This sparks  something in Julia. She hesitates, looking through an ope can be seen packing some clothes. Julia speaks to Terry i
Do you  fantasize about other people?
If I haven't  yet, I probably will by the time we're ready to leave. Hesitant  beat.
I've been  fantasizing about a guy.
Anyone we  know?
Blond. Good  looking. Nice body.
I'd like to  know that.
(hushed) He has a  Superman tattoo on his shoulder. Terry's mouth  drops. The girls move closer together.
No.
Yes.
No.
Yes .
When did this  start?
Sam's party. I  walked out of the bathroom and he was changing out of his his shirt ... and then he spotted me.
What did you  say? Keep going?
I got out of  there. But I've been fantasizing about him ever since.
Fuck yeah.  Power to the people.
But Paul is the  perfect boyfriend. Top to bottom. He's gorgeous. He's sma doctor.
(continuing) He never gets  upset about anything ...
What the hell  is wrong with me?
It's just a  fantasy.
Yeah, but when  I made love to Paul on grad night ... I thought of  him . Terry  stares.
Wow.
I know. Don't  tell Paul about this. I'd rather not test the whole "he n anything" part.
Are you  okay?
I don't know. I  think I'm flipping out. Seeing things in pictures. Thinki monster in my closet.
(rising) You're being  too sensitive. We woke up with our closet wide open and I it. Julia  reacts.
Your closet was  open?
Having to wash  my hair without an all-natural conditioner. That upsets m She walks out.  Julia sits quietly in the living room, left alone with he thoughts.
Julia is  walking down the hallway. She happens to pass the bathroo slightly open.
Within the  bathroom. The BLOND STUDENT is toweling off. Completely n plainly visible on his shoulder. His eyes lock on hers. Julia REACTS,  and runs straight into Paul. She JUMPS.
Jesus. You  scared me.
I'm sorry.
It's okay. I  wasn't looking.
I'm going for a  run.
Okay. See you  when you get back. (remembers) Oh, Paul? Don't  leave the closet door open anymore, all right?
(confused) Huh?
The closet.  Last night. You left it open.
I closed it  after I got my sweatshirt.
Did not.
Serious. I  thought you opened it.
Wasn't me. A moment.
Well damn,  Julia. Your monster isn't just noisy, he's also inconside He kisses her  on the cheek and takes off. Julia stands alone in the emp running down her spine.

The door slowly  creaks open. Julia stands in the doorway, surveying the c and claustrophobic space despite its size. Clothes draped boxes stacked on shelves. Shadows. Julia moves  inside and pulls a string hanging from a light bulb which Tick-tick. The bulb stays dark. She tries again. Tick-tick. The light still  won't come on. Julia carefully  looks through some of the clothes. Nothing. She kneels do floor. A long CREAKING  behind her. The natural light fades. Julia looks  over her shoulder, a bit skittish, as the closet door eas doorjamb. But there's nobody there. Just the faintest hin Julia keeps  searching through the clutter. Moving shoes and boxes out Searching. Then, she spots  something glittering in the ribbon of light coming from t small object resting in the corner. Julia reaches down an

Small and  intricate with erratic markings. Twisted and strangely or texture of the metal is almost completely alien. Julia holds the  metal into the light. Extremely curious. Behind her, a sh CRASH. Julia  SCREAMS, dropping the object and whirling around as a car behind her. Tumbling from one of the shelves above. Old s floor. Julia catches  her breath. Heart pounding. On the floor,  the metal object sparkles in the light. A draft HISSES th door.
The Range Rover  races down the empty road.
Julia sits  behind the wheel. Her eyes intense. She looks over at the both her purse and the metal object are located.
The Range Rover  streaks out of the woods towards Santa Mira.
Julia walks up  the front steps leading to the library -- a weathered bui the town square. A banner hangs over the front entrance.

head_text.subj: WELCOME TO THE FOUNDER'S DAY FAIR

text: The stacks are  deserted and still. Julia sits at a reading table, flippi surrounded by long rows of bookshelves.
Julia flips  from page to page, allowing momentary glimpses of various werewolves, witches, a ghastly thing crawling out from un
as she puts  down the book and grabs another from a stack on the table starts paging through.

As Julia finds  a drawing of a sleeping child. Just beyond the bed is an horrid face a MONSTER watching the child from within. Julia shivers  down to her soul. A familiar feeling of late. A slight  SQUEAKING catches her attention. She looks across the rea

Ten years old.  Tow-haired. Sitting a few tables away but almost directly wearing a Superman shirt. He smiles  timidly and waves. Julia waves back. A THUMP behind  her. Julia turns and looks over her shoulder. She barely shadow slipping across the wall in the stacks. The SCRAPING of  chair legs against the cold floor. Julia looks back towar sitting. The chair is pushed back and empty. Another  THUMPING in the stacks. Then silence. A feeling of  anxiety washes over Julia as she grabs some of the books
It's getting  dark. Moonshadows shift across the lawn.

Soft rock seeps  from a pair of portable compact disc player speakers. Pau grass and some zigzag papers and starts to roll a joint. toasted. Cardboard boxes and  candles are everywhere. Sam is sitting  off to himself. He's still drawing on his pad. Julia is r from the library.
(takes  a hit) Monsters.  Symbols and dream images. Now you see, I don't agree with everything has some kind of physical representation. Peop with this stuff.
You did a good  job last night. Julia hands him  the metal object from the closet.
And this? What  do you make of this?
Where'd you  find it?
In the closet  you  didn't leave open.
What's she  talking about?
(wearisome) My girlfriend  believes in the Boogeyman.
I never said it  was the Boogeyman. Maybe it's some primeval energy that c human beings. This could be the physical representation o
Julia. It's  piece of shit.
I disagree. Julia turns  hopefully to Terry --
Yes?
It's the  physical representation of a piece of shit. Pot-induced  laughter. Julia takes back the object.
You're not  being objective about this. Have either of you ever been scared?
I'm scared  right now that you've smoked too much.
Paul ...
Okay. Sure.  I've been really scared.
Like when? Beat.
Maybe when we  hit the dog. Sam looks  unsettled.
You mean  this? Sam tosses his  sketch pad into the center of the floor. Everyone leans f look at Sam's detailed drawing of --
Completely  fleshed out with distinct mechanical parts hinged into fl accurate as a photograph.

(cont'd) That thing we  hit on the road. It wasn't a dog. It wasn't some primeval (then) It was a  monster. Julia picks up  the drawing as Paul peers over her shoulder. The picture unsettling in the flickering firelight. It almost looks  alive.
It's late. The  fire is dwindling. Terry and Sam have both passed out. Ju floor, staring at Sam's drawing while resting in Paul's l
I can't believe  Sam drew this.
I can. He's  been acting like a freak. Beat.
You think we  could've been wrong?
About what?
About the dog.  Maybe the next day when Sam and I went back to the road . wrong body.
Can we drop  this? Please?
I just want to  know ...
(clipped) Stop.
I just want to  know what's going on.
Nothing's going  on. Here, give me the drawing.
I'm not done  yet.
Your hands are  shaking. Come on, Julia. Give yourself a break. She hands the  drawing pad to him. Paul puts it on the couch.
We need to talk  about this.
Tomorrow. Just  relax. Paul begins  stroking her hair. Gently and repeatedly.
Just for a  minute. Julia looks  really tired. She closes her eyes for a moment as Paul's the room. The she opens them, turns her head and gazes at
Sitting in a  chair. Smoking a cigarette. Smiling down at her. She cranks her  head and looks deeply into her boyfriend's eyes. He smirk her hair.
(cont'd) Nice.
(soft) You're tired.  Go to sleep. Her breathing  becomes more steady. In the  distance, a SOUND begins to permeate the cabin ...
Grinding and  drumming like the churning of a large factory. A calming and soothing noise, drifting  over ...

Quick FLASHES  OF IMAGES which are strung together: (a) A turbine  driven by a cloud of pumping steam. (b) The  Superman tattoo on the Blond Student's shoulder. (c) A Doberman  running across a road. (d) A man  limping along wearing leg braces and using steel crutches (e) A woman's  hands slipping over a young man's bare chest. (f) A back  brace being locked into place.
The stall door  at the far end of the bathroom eases open.

SOUND except for the HUMMING OF MACHINES. Julia stumbles  through the snake pit. MENTAL PATIENTS stagger around her dressed like homeless people. Staring into space. Bodies on their fingers. Lying in their own urine. Julia looks  skyward towards a SCREEN that doubles for a ceiling. Dark on the screen, looking down at them. A pair of  ORDERLIES gently take Julia's arm and lead her out of the Julia looks at  the wall as she walks.
shadows move across the wall. Almost like ripples in wate But the shadows gradually become the GROTESQUE  silhouettes of HUMAN BODY PARTS -- arms, legs, heads, fee rocking gently from hooks
Blood trickles  down over the Superman tattoo.
Clawed fingers  slide around the open stall door.
PERSON is having a seizure. Propped against the wall. Sha and body are entirely covered with braces that form a met
A gynecology  exam. A woman's legs are held open by stirrups. A pair of rubber gloves cruelly insert a large alien-looking METAL nothing but sharp tentacles and angles -- between the leg
A woman  shrieking through rotting teeth and blood.

Julia steps  into the surgical room. The LITTLE GIRL  from Sam's party is resting on a gurney. Her small body i metal bands. Her blonde curls draped over the edge. Her e nothing. SOMETHING ELSE LURCHES INTO the room. MOVING

head_text.subj: IN THE SHADOWS. A SURGEON ENCLOSED IN METAL BRACES AND HO

text: ALIEN-LOOKING shears in HIS HANDS.

head_text.subj: THE SURGEON OPENS THE SHEARS OVER THE GIRL'S

text: Julia tries to  scream. No sound comes out. The shears close. Several drops  of BLOOD ... then a BLONDE CURL ... hit the tile floor. The  SOUND of the MACHINES is interrupted by  GLASS BREAKING.

LIVING ROOm - NIGHT Julia lurches  awake. Paul and Terry  are lying immobile on the floor. Hundreds of candles have the room, bathing the cabin in a dull amber glow. There is NO  SOUND. Julia starts to  rise to her feet. Her fingers graze something sharp. She fingers away from ...

Julia discovers  a small ribbon of blood trickling from her index finger. notices -- SAM ... Sitting behind  the couch. His eyes are intense as he erases something fr Julia walks around him until she can see the sketch.

Sam erases the  picture, working from the shoulders up. There is still  NO SOUND. Julia is  dumbfounded. She hears a slight noise coming from somewhe small HISSING sound. Soft and unobtrusive. Julia looks  around. The sound seemed to come from behind her. But the room. Her friends are still asleep. Sam is concentrating More HISSING.  Unmistakable this time. A diminutive SCRAPING, almost lik icy glass, slithering out from a darkened hallway. She moves  towards the sound.

Julia creeps  into the hallway until she can barely see the rows of bed are closed shut. The SCRAPING  sound rises up again. Much closer. Behind one of the bedr Beckoning. Julia reaches  out for the doorknob.

The door opens.  Julia's stomach rises into her throat. Terror floods her Resting on the bed is a BODY BAG. So smeared  with blood that the corpse inside isn't visible except fo bulk. Something SCRATCHES on the BODY BAG from  INSIDE. Julia's body  goes rigid. She can't force herself to move. The body bag is slowly unzipped from the  inside. Stretching down the length of the plastic until t The corpse inside is still hidden. As if drawn by  some alien force, Julia moves to the bed. Her entire body She reaches out  and carefully peels back the plastic. Resting within  the body bag is THE LITTLE GIRL. Eyes puffed shut. Hair s skin is livid. Her face is ghostly white and smeared with Julia is frozen  in place. Heart pounding. Terrified.

head_text.subj: BLINK OPEN AS SHE SHRIEKS BLOODY MURDER.

text: Julia is  startled awake and groggily looks around the room. Paul a the process of getting up.
Look who's  up. (smiles) You sleep  well? Julia STARES  back. She looks pretty freaked.
(cont'd) Uh-oh.
I didn't sleep  well either. I dreamt that all these cockroaches were eat
You want to  trade? Right before I woke up, my head exploded and all t out.
Where's  Sam?
Probably went  to bed. Terry nods as  she rises to her feet.
I need a hairbrush. And a  facial. She stumbles  into the hallway. Paul turns to Julia.
You had  nightmares too?
Worst ones I've  had in a long time. I thought I was hallucinating. Paul winces and  rubs his temples.
(cont'd) What's  wrong?
Headache. I'll  be fine. Terry briskly  walks out the hallway. She looks alarmed.
You guys.  Something's wrong.
The group walks  towards one of the bedroom doors.
It's Sam. I  can't get the door open. Paul tries the  doorknob. The door won't budge. Paul KNOCKS.
Sam, open  up. No answer. He  POUNDS harder.
(cont'd) Sam?
He won't  answer.
Maybe he can't  answer. Paul shoves  hard against the door. But it still won't give.
What about the  bathroom door? It connects to your room.
I tried it.  It's locked. Paul turns the  doorknob and throws all his weight against the door, tryi down. No such luck.
(voice  rising) Sam
He tries again  and again. WHOOMPH! .... WHOOMPH! .... WHOOMPH! The  door inches open. Just a crack.
(cont'd) Help me out  with this. Paul and Julia  push on the door, forcing it wider.

Paul struggles  through the aperture, slipping underneath a mattress that the door, and stumbles into the room. The bedroom is a disaster area . Clothes and  smashed glass cover the floor. Mirrors have been shattere furniture and portions of the bed have been piled in fron an almost impassible barricade. The window is wide open, in the breeze. Julia and Terry  make their way into the room. Stupefied.
Careful of the  glass. Don't step on it. Total silence.  The group stares at the room. Taking it in. Trying to com
What  happened?
(frozen) You got me.
Paul and Terry  are walking along the trail. Searching.
(calling) Sam? No reply. Her  words sound hollow in the empty forest as they keep movin pine trees that obscure them from view. A soft breeze  rises up and HISSES through the trees.

Julia is  cleaning the mess in the room. She's just finished tossin broken glass into a garbage bag when she FLINCHES and dra back. The finger has  a scab on it. Exactly where she cut it in the dream. Drie wound.
Terry looks  beside herself. Paul and Julia are seated.
He must have  gotten out through the window. That's the only thing I ca
We have to call  the police.
You looked  everywhere?
Everywhere near  the cabin. But we can't cover every square inch of forest
He might be  sick. He might need help.
I can't  understand why he'd do something like this.
He was acting  nuts. Really nuts.
(impatient) I need a  phone.
Wait. I've got  my cell. Paul fishes the  cell phone out of his pocket. He hands it to her.
Almost on cue.  Terry glances over at her friends, then clicks the receiv
Hello? (beat) Sam
Julia and Paul  sit up in their seats.
(cont'd) Where are you?  ... No, where are you? ... (beat) How did you get  there? ... Terry hurriedly  grabs a pen. She starts writing on a pad.
(cont'd) Just a minute.  I'm writing it down. Market Street. The Ramada. I think I (beat) Sam, what's  going on? What happened? ... (then) Sam? ... SAM?  ... She hangs up  the phone.
Where is  he?
San  Francisco.
What?
I don't know.  He wants me to meet him. My brother has an apartment up t but I have a spare key. I guess I could stay there. Beat.
You still want  to call the police? Silence. Terry  doesn't respond to this. Outside an open  window, the WIND HISSES through the trees.

An empty bus  station consisting of a single room with a CLERK sitting Julia and Paul are sitting on a pair of chairs, waiting p Terry is using  a phone booth outside. She hangs up and walks into the de
Did you get his  parents?
It was the  wrong number.
Didn't Sam give  you that number?
Maybe I wrote  it down wrong. Terry winces a  bit. She massages her legs.
Are you  okay?
My legs are  killing me.
You sure you  don't want us to drive you?
Nah. You have  to stick around for the movers. I'll be fine. The bus arrives  in front of the depot.
(cont'd) There's my  ride. Terry grabs her  suitcase. Julia hands her a slip of paper.
This is Paul's  cell number. You call us. Let us know what happens.
I just need to  talk to him. Don't call the police or anything until I've that.
Okay.
Thanks. Terry hugs  Julia. Paul gives her a quick kiss on the cheek.
Remember. Call  us.
I will. Carrying her  suitcase, Terry backs toward the door, smiling sadly at J opens it.
(cont'd) It'll be okay.  Everything's okay. Her voice  resonates with desperate hope rather than confidence. She Paul places his  arms around Julia as they watch the bus leave the station
Julia is  cleaning up. She kneels down and picks up some of the mel bottles. Paul walks into  room holding a broken picture frame.
I talked to the  movers.
Why didn't they  show up?
The company has  no record of the order. Beat.
What?
I know. It's  crazy.
Are they coming  now?
It'll take them  a while to work us into the schedule -- get a van out her everything.
How long?
Three days.
(exhausted) Shit. Paul holds out  the mangled frame.

I also found  this in the guest bedroom. Sam knocked one of the packing inside. Julia takes a  look at the frame. It's the same picture from her room of mother. The broken glass has torn the photograph.
(cont'd) I wasn't sure  if you wanted to keep it.
No. I've got  one. Beat.

(cont'd) You know this  is the only picture I have of my mother? (beat) She was always  taking pictures of us, but we never got any of her. (emotional) If I didn't  have this, I couldn't prove that I had a mother.
That's not  true. Another  beat.
I'm so worried  about Sam. Julia drowns in  her thoughts. Paul touches her cheek.
Let's get outta  here.
(smiles) Good idea.

I'll get my  keys. Paul walks out.  Julia places the frame on the coffee table. She notices  something on the floor. Julia squints. It's a small objec ... almost hidden from view. Julia reaches into the shado ANOTHER PIECE OF METAL with STRANGE markings.  EXACTLY LIKE THE ONE FROM THE CLOSET. Julia stares at  the object in her palm. Surprised.
(to  herself) Where are these  coming from?
A warm summer  afternoon. The entire town has congragated in a park with the ocean. MUSIC and NOISE. A huge banner draped over the

head_text.subj: CELEBRATES THE 45TH ANNUAL FOUNDER'S DAY FESTIVAL

text: Julia navigates  her way past the booths and thrill rides that have been e watches some passersby.
as A MOTHER talks on a cell phone while her six year-old sleeve. Trying to get her attention. The mother keeps pus she talks. Julia observes  this scene until she hears ...
I'm your  mother. Julia steps out  of the crowd. Searches for the voice.
WOMAN is shadowing a COLLEGE-AGE GIRL walking with her bo to ignore her.
I'm your mother  ... I'm your mother ... I'm your mother ... The couple  walks faster. The Homeless Woman is left behind.
(cont'd) (futile) I'm your mother  ... Julia stares  helplessly.

Spinning  merrily in the center of the park. Bright lights. Loud CA kids and teenagers occupy the horses and benches. Julia slowly  walks towards the carousel, snapping pictures of the chil lights. Behind her, the sound of a SCREAMING CHILD rises laughter. She turns and finds a two year old BABY sitting shoulders, crying and pointing at --
Wearing his  blue Superman shirt. He's sitting on a swing set by himse He makes eye  contact with Julia. Waves timidly. She smiles at him and
Gears turning.  The poles spearing the horses rising and falling into the rotating near the grass. The CALLIOPE  MUSIC becomes the HUMMING of MACHINES.
Julia is  wandering through a maze of shooting galleries. She searc of teenagers and children at the booths. Finally, she loc PAUL ... Approaching her  with a large Teddy Bear under his arm.
Where did you  go?
Basketball  toss. I won this for you. Julia smiles at  the bear.
You sure you  want to give him up?
(nice  smile) I think he'd  crowd my Barbie collection. Julia kisses  him. He kisses her back and winces in pain.
You okay?
Head still  hurts.
Need some  aspirin?
Already took  some. I'll be okay. Paul notices  that they've wandered into a row of PSYCHIC and TAROT CAR
(cont'd) Hey, look. Want  to get your palm read?
As long as  you're feeling up to it.
I am. Come  on. Julia spots  another booth with a sign overhead: "THE PAST THROUGH POS
Just a minute.  You go to the palm reader. I want to check out this one.
"The past  through possessions?" (unimpressed) Scam city.
And palm  reading isn't? She's got him  there.
All right. I'll  meet you over there.
Thanks. She kisses him  quickly. They split up.
Paul approaches  the booth. An  African-American woman in her mid-forties, TESS, sits beh and upbeat. Wearing more colors in her clothing than even provide.
Can you read my  palm? She grins.
You got five  bucks?

Julia walks to  the front counter of the booth. A pair of women  are sitting behind the counter, but the one who sticks ou psychic and clairvoyant. She wears a purple kaftan which weakness for ice cream and cookies.
Can we help  you, honey?
You can tell me  things just by holding something of mine. Right?
Absolutely. I  have a perfect track record. I found two missing children and helped the state police catch a murderer in '81.
Wow. That's  amazing.
(sourly) My  grandchildren aren't quite as impressed. (a  little brighter) What did you  want me to look at? Julia reaches  into her pocket and gently places something on the counte Rosemary.
Tess takes  Paul's hand.
So what do you  want to know?
It's kinda  stupid. But I sorta wanted to know about my Dad. If I sho
(knowingly) You and your  father don't get along.
No.
Something  happened?
My parents got  divorced when I was sixteen. I got into a fight with him. He bows his  head a little. A tough subject for him.
Let's take a  look ... Tess cocks her  head a little to the side. She looks confused.
(cont'd) (soft) I'll be  damned.
What's  wrong?
Well kid, you  might be the first person to make me hang up my fortune t the palm makes sense, and this one doesn't.
How do you  mean?
According to  this, you don't exist. OFF Paul, his  face turning white.
Rosemary  handles one of the metal objects, turning it over in her as she goes through this ritual.
This is  interesting.
Let me guess.  They came from a vacuum cleaner, right? Beat.
Machines.
Excuse me?
This came from  a machine. But not a household appliance.
Where did it  come from? Rosemary turns  the object over in her palm. Over and over.
Something that  was alive. Julia leans  forward in her seat.
But you just  said it came from a machine.
I know.
So how can a  machine be alive?
I don't make  the news. I just report it.

I found the  larger one inside of a closet. Do you know how it got the Rosemary  continues meditating. Turning the object over between her it. Gradually, she  falls into a trance. Her breathing slows.
We shed our  parts.
What?
And our  skin.
I'm sorry. What  are you talking about? Rosemary is  oblivious to anything around her.
But they need  to be replaced. Some of the parts we can find. (beat) Others need to  be harvested. The other  PSYCHIC seated next to Rosemary throws her a curious glan some money.

(cont'd) We'll wait on  the side of the road. Until one of the machines come. (beat) One of us will  be sacrificed. That will stop the machine. Then we can ta inside. (softer) We can use  their parts. Paul walks  up.
Julia? She motions for  him to be quiet.
We stopped the  machine. But there are more of the skins than we thought
Julia. Let's  take off.
Hold on.
We must wait.  More of us are needed to capture them.
What's she  talking about?
Wait just a  minute. Please. Beat. The objects  continue turning in her hand ... and turning ... and turn ...
There are more  of us now. We've surrounded them. But they're leaving too
Julia? ... and turning ...
We'll follow  them. We'll watch them. (beat) We'll take them  as the need for parts becomes necessary ...
(louder) Julia? The wind gently  HISSES through the booth's tent.
Maybe we'll  only take one ... (beat) Maybe we'll  take another ... and another ... and another ... and  another ... A sudden gust  of wind rises through the tent as ...

head_text.subj: THROUGHOUT THE PARK. LIGHTS START GOING OUT IN SECTIONS U

text: The sound of  mumbling and confusion seethes from the crowd. Julia rise Paul takes her into her arms as CHILDREN can be heard CRY park. Above them, the  wind HISSES through the trees.
Julia sits on  the porch. Paul is stretched out on the grass looking up
So the power  went out. That doesn't mean anything.
Did you hear  what she said?
No.
She was talking  about the accident. The night you hit that thing on the r that.
Julia, a  psychic tells you some random shit and then lets YOU make
She said it was  waiting for us.
Oh sure. An  animal was waiting for us to come along and run it down. explanation? Rotten home life? Was it taking Prozac?
It wanted to  stop the car.
Why?
Something about  needing parts.
If it needed  parts, it shouldn't have committed suicide.
She said there  were more of them.
Who cares what  she said? It doesn't mean anything.
But it's not  just that. Julia's voice  becomes soft. As if she were telling a secret.
(cont'd) I've also had  this feeling. Ever since Sam disappeared. I can't shake i
What is it?
I feel like  something's missing.
Something?
I don't know.  It's on the tip of my tongue. I just feel like ever since morning, something's not right. Like ... there's someone ...
Right. Sam.
It's not  Sam. (then) Did that palm  reader say anything strange to you. Anything at all? Paul hesitates.  He looks back at the night sky.
No. Beat.
Can I use your  phone?
A traditional  home. The phone rings and Connor comes charging down the it.
Hello?
Julia is  sitting on the couch.
Connor. It's  Julia.
Oh. I thought  you were someone else.
Nice to hear  your voice too.
You having  fun?
(understated) Not  exactly.
I got my PSAT's  back. 720 verbal. 690 math. You think that's good enough Berkeley?
You'll get in.  Listen, is Dad there?
No.
Well could you  leave him a message?
Uh-huh.
Tell him that  the movers didn't come, so I'll be here a few more days. some stuff of Mom's that he might want.
Okay.
Don't  forget.
Jesus. Show a  little faith. When have I ever forgotten something?
A piece of  developing paper is slipped into the tray basin. Julia gently  rocks the basin back and forth. A picture starts to manif
Paul splashes  his face with water. He looks worse than he did the night He grabs some  aspirin from the medicine cabinet.
Julia leans  forward to get a better view of the developing picture. A forming -- carousel horses, the vague outlines of poles a
Paul is  shirtless and doing one-armed push-ups. His muscles churn falls like a piston.
The picture has  come into view. The carousel. The children laughing as th And something  else ... An  irregularity. A dark form in the center of the carousel.
Paul's arm as he does push-ups, sweat beading on his bice rippling. The SOUND of  MACHINES pulsates and segues into ...

Julia takes the  picture out of the developing basin. WE MOVE INTO THE PHOTO - There's a dark SHAPE  standing in the middle of the carousel. Blurred and indis SILHOUETTE OR A SHADOW. EXCEPT THAT it's waving at the  camera.
Paul is sitting  on the couch, wearing a UCLA cross country tank top and t enters from the basement. She's carrying a stack of devel
Paul, you have  to see this. The picture came out, but there's something middle of it. Just like the other one of the shed. He looks at the  picture.
Looks like  someone on the carousel.
But there's no  features. It's like a shadow.
So there wasn't  enough light. Paul rubs his  forehead. Julia is genuinely concerned.
What's the  matter?
My head feels  worse.
Maybe you  should lie down.
I have to go  running.
No you  don't.
Of course I do.  Your body's like a machine. It needs upkeep.
Not when you're  physically ill.
I'll be  okay.
Paul ...
I'll be  okay. (about  the picture) Is that it?
Not  exactly. (beat) When I saw this  picture, I decided to look at the other one. Just for com
So? Julia takes out  another photograph.
I pulled this  one by mistake. The picture of that little girl from the She hands him  the picture.
(cont'd) Look. Paul's face  collapses into slack disbelief. THE LITTLE GIRL HAS DISAPPEARED from the  photo. Vanished. Paul turns to  Julia as she looks into his eyes with a mixture of fear a
(cont'd) What's going  on? This time, he  doesn't have an answer.
Murky and  still. A few shafts of sunlight permeate the gloom. Paul is jogging  along the trail, keeping a steady pace, the sounds of the him.
The trail  snakes towards a wooden bridge that spans over a tricklin across, the soles of his sneakers SLAPPING on creaking wo He moves deeper  into the woods.

A lonely part  of the woods where almost all the daylight is blocked out Paul jogs along  the trail when he slows to a halt, sweaty and out of brea His limbs are shivering. Paul cradles his head, shutting from obvious pain.

(very  soft) Oh God ....  make it stop ... He starts  walking forward again. Very slowly. A slight  TINKLING sound as he kicks something at his feet. His eye looks down ... There are several pieces of metal littering  the trail. Almost like nuts and bolts, but alien in their Paul reaches  down and picks one of the bolts up. Studies it. He keeps pieces of metal that lead off the footpath.
A darker spot  enclosed by pine trees. A few birds are singing overhead. Paul enters the  forest, pushing back branches, following the trail of dis freezes ... his eyes staring directly ahead at ...

Hanging from  branches. Scattered on the ground. Like the skin of a sna shed. Paul is  completely unsettled. He kneels down, picking up a flap o peeling it away from a steel ROD dripping with oozing sli still black in color but almost transparent in the murky The wind HISSES  through the trees, mussing Paul's hair. Paul drops the  piece of skin on the ground. The birds  abruptly stop singing in unison. The WIND CEASES. Paul looks  around the forest. The sudden quiet has got him spooked. stiffen. Paul can't even bring himself to move or breathe
Paul freaks and  whirls around, grabbing his shoulder to find
Clinging to  him. He rips it off and sprints for the footpath.
Paul sprints  out of the forest, running with blinding speed and adrena back. Behind him, the  wind HISSES through the trees again.
Julia comes up  from the basement. She hears COUGHING coming from the bat
Julia enters  the bathroom. Paul is retching and coughing into the toil his forehead. Pale as death. Shaking badly.
Paul? What's  wrong?
(feeble) Sick. She goes to  him. Rubs his shoulders as he COUGHS again.
Oh baby ... Julia brushes  the hair from his forehead. She freezes. Just above his  temple is a SCAB. No bigger than the head of an eraser. I Julia's finger.
(cont'd) Paul? Where did  this come from?
What?
This scab. Julia runs her  finger over the scab. Paul immediately reels from her tou through his head, furious.
Jesus! Fuck! Julia is  shocked by the severity of his reaction.
I'm sorry. Paul holds his  head tight. Almost near tears. Fighting pain.
Just don't  touch it.
How long has it  been there?
Ever since my  head started to hurt. (then) I think I'm  hallucinating.
What did you  see?
Skin ... like  it was shed ... and all of these metal pieces ... Julia is  terribly concerned now. His description frightens her, bu visage of calm.
Do you want to  see a doctor? I know there's one in Santa Mira.
I can see a  doctor in Los Angeles. (then) Look, I want to  get out of here, okay? Let's go home. Beat.
Okay. She squeezes  his shoulder and walks into --
Julia pulls out  their duffle bags and suitcases. Paul's cell  phone RINGS on the table. Julia snatches up the phone and
Hello? ... Yes?  ... (then) Wait a minute  ... slow down, I can't understand what you're saying ... Complete  astonishment storms Julia's face. Paul wanders in.
Who is it?
It's Terry.  Something went wrong.
Gloomy and  overcast. Storm clouds are brewing.
The Range Rover  pulls down a crowded street.
Julia is  sitting behind the wheel. Navigating traffic. Paul sits on  the passenger side, leaning against the window, his face glass. Somber and weak.
The twisted  remains of a car accident has brought everything to a nea are everywhere. An ambulance is parked along the curb, li Julia leans  forward to get a better look.
VICTIM presses a white towel against his thigh. Blood gus metal ROD sticks out of his leg.
The Range Rover  moves past the shredded cars involved in the accident. Tw street.
Summer rain is  falling. THUNDER ROLLS overhead. The Rover pulls  up to the sidewalk, directly in front of an extremely opu house.
Julia turns to  Paul who sits silently in the passenger seat. He doesn't
Sure you don't  want to come with me?
I'm too sick. I  need to stay someplace.
I'm worried  about leaving you here.
(shrugs) It's not like  he'll disown me.
I know.
And I really  need him right now. More THUNDER.  Julia kisses his cheek.
I'm taking the  cell phone. You call me.
Promise.
See a  doctor.
I will. Paul opens the  passenger door and steps out into the rain. Julia watches house. Then, she pulls away from the curb.
A nice house.  Large and affluent. The DOORBELL  CHIMES. A few moments  pass before a sullen FIGURE arrives at the front door and revealing ...
standing on the  front porch. His wet hair plastered to his forehead, rain cheeks, his handsome face turned pallid and colorless. He manages a  sheepish smile.

Dad. Standing at the  door is a man in his mid-fifties, MR. LOOMIS. A severe pr and weathered face. He stares at Paul without any sign of Paul notices  the slight. He presses onward. A bit haltingly. Still hop connect.
(cont'd) I was hoping we  could talk ... (beat) I know we  haven't done much of that recently, but still ... (beat) I was  hoping. Beat.

(cont'd) I'm in a lot of  trouble. I'm getting sick ... and I was hoping ...  (beat) I was hoping  you could help. Paul is having  difficulty speaking. He's almost reduced to tears as he s stinging rain.
(cont'd) I want to come  home. Please Dad. (desperate) Please let me  come home. A moment of  silence.
(cont'd) Please? His father  stands steely eyed. His voice is icy and distant.
I don't know  you. Paul is  devastated. He can barely utter a sound.
I'm your  son. Agonizing  beat.
I don't have a  son. (then) I don't know  you. He slowly  closes the door. Paul begins weeping openly.
Dad ... The door is  shut in his face. Nothing can be heard except for the rai
Julia is standing near the entrance. Waiting  patiently. A figure across the street catches Julia's  attention -- a HOMELESS MAN stumbling down the sidewalk, shaking a rattle.

Julia? Julia turns  around, searching, not immediately recognizing the figure approaches her -- It's Terry. But  her once perfect appearance has become harsh and drawn. H colored dark brown. There are sagging circles under her e colorless. She moves quickly. Nervously. Julia is  shocked.
Terry? Terry's hands  tremble.
I'm glad you  came. You don't have any idea how scared I've been.
Why did you  change your hair? Terry is about  to answer when a BABY starts crying in the market. Fear t face.
We can't stay  here.
Why?
Where are you  parked?
On the  street.
Good. If we  keep moving, they might have trouble tracking us. Terry takes  Julia's arm and leads her out of the market.
Terry is moving  at a swift pace. She keeps looking back over her shoulder up. Rain drenches them.
What the hell  is going on? Where's Sam?
He's dead. This almost  sends Julia reeling. Her mouth falls open.
What?
There's three  things you should remember. Three things.
What happened  to Sam?
First, whenever  you see a baby or a kid crying, keep moving. Children can your warning.
Warning against  who?
Second, they  can control anything electrical or mechanical. Lamps. Car
Terry, you're  not making any sense.
Third -- they  can change things. They can make you disappear.
Tell me what  happened to Sam.
I am telling  you. (terrified) They took him.  They made him disappear. Julia stops  walking. Speechless.
A young COLLEGE  STUDENT is typing on his powerbook, oblivious to the TRAN sidewalk, head buried in his knees, a sign at his feet re
POWERBOOK. A soft  whirring noise  seeping from the computer as the student types. The WHIRRING  becomes the HUMMING OF MACHINES. The Range Rover  appears on the street and moves past.
They take away  your identity. People stop remembering you. Your place in
Julia is behind  the wheel. Terry is devouring a cigarette.
That's how they  get you. By making people not even care about you anymore
Did you try  Sam's parents? Did you get the right number this time?
The number I  called at the bus station was his parents. (cryptic) We didn't hit a  dog on the road.
But I saw  it.
They switched  bodies.
Who are "they?"  A cult? Killers? Terry starts  laughing to herself. Tears welling in her eyes. Hopeless.
You have no  idea.  No idea what you're dealing with. (then) They don't even  belong here. They're like ... like  machines . That's what Sam said. Like  machines with all this skin and moving parts.
They're  machines?
Monsters.  They're monsters, Julia. Julia stops at  a light.
crosses the street in front of them. He's just a yuppie w Terry stiffens in her seat, watching him suspiciously. Then, almost as  an aside, he winks at her.
(cont'd) Drive.
I can't.  There's a red.
Then make a  right. Just keep driving. Julia is  growing frightened by Terry's paranoia.
The Rover makes  a right turn and cruises down another block.
Terry keeps her  eyes riveted on the PEOPLE on the sidewalk. She's practic
Remember when  we hit that thing with the car?  (hushed) It wasn't an  accident. It was a set-up.  They planned it all along.
How do you know  this?
Sam told me. He  figured everything out.
Why are they  coming after us? What do they want with us?
They have flesh  and metal parts in their bodies. Sometimes they shed what other parts keep getting worn out or lost. So they take p new parts.
(soft) That's not  possible.
They wear the  skin. That's why you don't notice them. Half of the time people's skin. Or they're hiding in dark places. Alleys. Julia is  horrified.
Terry ...  please stop.
They take other  parts too. Whatever they need. They're scavengers. No sen remorse.
I don't believe  this.
That's why they  came after us. They got Joey first. At the cabin. Julia is  dumbfounded.
Joey?
That's what Sam  saw. That's why he left. He woke up and got a look at the doing to Joey ...
Terry ...
Stripping him
taking his skin off ... Julia pulls  over to the curb and stops.
Who is Joey?  What are you talking about?
(amazed) You don't  remember?
No.
There were five  of us. He came up in his own car. He was Paul's best frie the same thing for Christ sakes.
There were only  four of us. You. Me. Paul. Sam. Terry is  shaking now. Complete fright.
They got to  you. They got to you.
Nobody got to  me. Terry starts  collecting her things.
Look, could you  drop me off at my brother's apartment? I need to pick up to the airport.
Where are you  going?
To see my  parents.
You can't just  leave. Terry starts  weeping. Grabbing her legs and squeezing them.
They put things  in my legs so they can track me. It hurts.
(very  concerned) Terry? What can  I do to help you? Terry takes her  hand. Her eyes pleading.
Remember me.  Please remember me. From the street  outside the car, the sound of a TODDLER CRYING can be hea around. She stares out the windshield at the screaming ch
(cont'd) They found me  again. Before Julia  can react, Terry bolts from the car.
Terry! Julia  pursues.
Julia pushes  and shoves her way along the sidewalk. Terry is running l unabated terror. Terry rushes  down into a subway entrance. Julia follows.

People are  crowded on the platform, waiting as a BART train rushes i The doors open.  Passengers move off the train. Others get on. Julia rushes  down the stairs and pushes past the arriving commuters. T Terry. Julia keeps searching. Looks right. Then left. Fin boarding the BART train.

Terry!  Wait! Julia rushes  forward, squirming through the crowd, until she reaches t SLAM CLOSED. She looks through the windows, trying to fin crowd inside. The train  starts to move. Standing at one  of the train's passenger windows, his face and palms pres is --

Staring  directly at her. Dark circles around his eyes. He smiles at  Julia. His teeth are made of metal. Julia stands  thunderstruck. The BOY in the window moves past. The train  shoots into the awaiting tunnel. Julia is left standing f the platform. Near the subway  entrance, a HOMELESS MAN with HOOKS FOR HANDS is convulsi the wall. Eyes wide open. Shaking horribly and staring at

Quiet and dimly  lit. Several of the lights are burnt out, leaving the hal shadows. The elevator  doors open. Terry exits and moves quickly down the hallwa terrified. Sick. She arrives at  an apartment. Terry fumbles with her keys. A soft

in the hallway. Deep and  hollow. Terry spins around, the keys JINGLING in her hand Nothing there.  The hall appears to be empty and dark. One of the lights and  buzzing softly, providing  scant illumination. She takes a  step back ... A soft TINKLING  sound at her feet. Terry looks down to find a few pieces floor. Nuts and bolts. Rods. Alien in design. Terry's  paranoia rises to a fever pitch. She turns the key in the door.
Terry shuts the door. Locks it. Switches on the  lights. Drops her KEYS and CELL PHONE on a coffee table. She moves briskly into --
An open  suitcase on the bed. Terry snatches up a PLANE TICKET and into her purse. Slams the suitcase closed.

Terry leaves  the bedroom, carrying the suitcase, and walks straight to She collects her keys and her cell phone from the table. The lights in the apartment simultaneously go  out. Terry is caught  entirely off guard. She spins around to face the living r Nothing.

head_text.subj: AT THE FRONT DOOR. A STEADY POUNDING. THE BANGING GOES ON

text: Terry's  breathing quickens. She puts the suitcase down. A crack of  THUNDER reverberates outside. Moving with the  cautious steps of a small child, she walks towards the fr The only sound is her FRIGHTENED BREATHING. She arrives a looks out into the empty hall.

head_text.subj: STARES BACK AT HER THROUGH THE PEEPHOLE.

text: Moving right in  front of the door. One of its yellow eyes piercing throug midnight skin pierced with metal bolts and rods.

The DOOR  RATTLES like it's going to break off its hinges. Somethin against the wood. Terry tears  through the apartment, feet POUNDING. She rushes into the The front door  in the living room BREAKS OPEN.
Terry SLAMS the  bedroom door and locks it. Backs away towards the bed, wh

Grabbing hold  of her ankle. Fused together from rotting flesh, human pa Terry pitches forward, SCREAMING, falling to her hands an The hand starts  dragging her under the bed. Terry kicks and  claws on the floor. Somehow manages to free herself from goes for the window and pulls it open. Steps outside. The entire bed  is OVERTURNED and tossed aside.

Terry is  immediately drenched by the storm. The door within her be CRASHING OPEN, followed by a ROARING unlike anything on t Terry rushes  down the fire escape, FEET BANGING on the metal steps. Bu tracks when she notices --
Standing in the  alley far below. Looking up at her. Waiting. A sound rises  up behind her. THE SOUND OF FOOTSTEPS BANGING DOWN THE FI PURSUIT.
(horrified) Oh God ... Terry  desperately goes to a window. She pulls it open, stepping
The apartment  floor is being renovated. Plastic tarps cover the doors a through the hallway, SCREAMING WILDLY as she POUNDS on th

Terry rockets  around the corner. She presses the elevator door button f The sound of  CROAKING and HISSING fills the hallway. The elevator  doors slide open. Terry lunges  into the elevator, hits for the lobby, then starts BEATIN door close button. Several shadows  appear in the hallway. Getting closer. Terry SCREAMS  WILDLY and keeps pounding the button. The bizarre  HISSING becomes a FRIGHTFUL ROAR just as ... The elevator  doors pull shut. Closing on the unseen things in the hall
The car starts going down. Floor lights blink above  the door. 8 ... 7 ... 6 ... Terry punches out 9-1-1 on the cell phone's keypad. Nothing comes  through the receiver. Only static.
Come on ...  come on ... She dials  again.
More static  over the cell phone. Terry has started crying in anguish to an abrupt halt. The doors stay  closed. Terry looks  above the elevator doors. The floor light reads --
(Basement) Terry starts  pressing for the lobby. The elevator won't move. She pres button, the alarm button, anything at all. Nothing respon
(cont'd)

Nothing. Futile  silence. She's about to try dialing on the cell phone aga WHUMP. A heavy  thudding sound above the elevator car roof. The light ove candle. Terry gazes at the failing light, then tracks her door in the roof. A few more hollow THUMPS . Terry is  petrified. She takes a step backward. The light flashes o creating a strobe light effect. Behind her, the  elevator doors silently pull open. Terry's gaze is  still focussed on the ceiling trap door. Behind her, the black. She continues moving backwards towards the open el after step, completely unaware ...

head_text.subj: LEAPS OUT OF THE DARK AND GRABS HER.

text: In the moment  it takes to draw a breath and scream, it's already over. The light goes  out.
The lobby is  vacant and terribly still. The elevator doors remain clos sounds coming from the shaft far below. Then  nothing.
The sound of a  PHONE LINE RINGING. Julia is  sitting inside of the parked Range Rover, the cell phone ear.
(from  phone) Hello?
Hello ... is  this Mr. Alba?
Yes.
I'm sorry to  call you so late ...
(overlapping) Who is  this?
This is Julia  Levin. We met a few days ago at graduation. I'm a friend Beat.
Who?
Terry. Your  daughter? More  silence.
(cont'd) Hello?
I don't have a  daughter.
Excuse me?
You must have  the wrong number.
(beat) No, this is the  right number ... CLICK! The MAN  hangs up the phone on the other line.

(cont'd) Hello? Julia stares at  the cell phone in stunned confusion, until a sharp pain c hand. She FLINCHES and nearly drops the phone. Julia chec finger. The WOUND HAS  GROWN. An infected red spot with a open hole in the cente seems to be rotting around it, allowing the wound to expa
A small box of  aspirin are taken from the shelf. Paul tightens  his fist around the box, shutting his eyes, fighting the in his head. He takes a deep breath and moves to the regi
Need anything  else?
(weak) No. The  cashier rings him up.
Four  thirty-two. Paul flips open  his wallet. His face drops into shock. There's nothing  inside his wallet. No credit cards. No money. No driver's thing.
(cont'd) Something  wrong? Paul can barely  speak.
Um ... I  must've brought the wrong wallet. Sorry. Paul walks out  of the store.
Paul stops  outside, running his fingers through his hair, digging th
(shaking  his head) That's not  possible ... that's not possible ... A SHAPE grabs  his shoulder. Paul spins around.
LADY stands behind him. Pleading eyes. Dishevelled and ca holds up the drooping sleeve where a hand once was.
Help me. They  took my hand. Paul stumbles  back. Horrified.
